title: Cleaning up the ‘world’s highest junkyard’ is becoming a fashion statement: What rubbish! It’s Everest
text:
According to a recent report, PM Narendra Modi’s Swachh Bharat campaign is not only going transnational but is also scaling new heights of endeavour. In a concerted six-week clean-up drive, a 14-member team put together by the Nepali government working in tandem with environment groups, retrieved some 10 tons of garbage – including plastic water bottles, tin cans, and discarded climbing equipment – from altitudes as high as 26,000-plus feet on Mount Everest, the world’s highest peak.

Decades of near-unregulated climbing by mountaineers – which included a contingent of the People’s Liberation Army of China, which years ago claimed to have scaled the peak sans the use of oxygen and singing inspirational Mao songs – had turned the mightiest of Himalayas, named after British surveyor George Everest, into the ‘world’s highest junkyard’ which might more aptly be called Mount Neverest.

Ridding Everest of its accumulated rubbish is making not only environmental but also economic good sense. The high-altitude trash is being turned by local entrepreneurs into a variety of designer goods, ranging from drinking glasses, to utensils, to light fixtures, which are being snapped up by five-star hotels and fashionable boutiques which can legitimately claim to be high-end. But perhaps the best reason to justify the retrieval of Everest’s junk would be contained in a repeat of Mallory’s famous response as to why he wanted to climb the mountain: “Because it is there.”
